li.p: Is it possible to find the Taylor series expansion for a given function f without computing and evaluating various derivatives of f?
Can we differentiate or integrate a Taylor series similar to how we differentiate or integrate a polynomial? If so, how does doing so affect the values of x for which the Taylor series converges?
What is an alternating series and how can we determine whether or not it converges? How do the partial sums of a converging alternating series accurately estimate its exact sum?

introduction.p: So far, we have focused our attention on a collection of five basic functions functions \frac{1}{1-x}, \ln(1+x), \sin(x), \cos(x), and e^x and their Taylor series centered at a = 0. One of the reasons we were able to find these Taylor series is the clear patterns in the derivatives of each of these functions. While we can always use Definition to find the first few terms of the Taylor series, for most functions it is challenging to find a pattern among the various derivatives that allows us to state the general nth term of the series.
In Preview Activity, we explore this issue and investigate a different approach to finding the Taylor series of a given function.

subsection.title: Using substitution and algebra to find new Taylor series expressions
subsection.p: The substitution technique we used in Preview Activity can be used to find the Taylor series for any function whose structure is similar to that of a Taylor series we already know.

example.statement: Find the Taylor series expansion for g(x) = x^4 \cos(x^3) and determine the x-values for which the series converges.

solution.p:
Because \cos(x^3) is part of the function whose Taylor series we seek, we start with the familiar series for \cos(x). We know that
f(u) = \cos(u) = 1 - \frac{1}{2!}u^2 + \frac{1}{4!}u^4 - \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{(2n)!} u^{2n} + \cdots
for all real numbers u.

By letting u = x^3 in Equation, it follows that
\cos(x^3) = 1 - \frac{1}{2!}(x^3)^2 + \frac{1}{4!}(x^3)^4 - \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{(2n)!} (x^3)^{2n} + \cdots , so
\cos(x^3) = 1 - \frac{1}{2!}x^6 + \frac{1}{4!}x^{12} - \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{(2n)!} x^{6n} + \cdots . Then, multiplying both sides of Equation by x^4, we find that
g(x) = x^4 \cos(x^3) = x^4 - \frac{1}{2!}x^{10} + \frac{1}{4!}x^{16} - \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{(2n)!} x^{6n+4} + \cdots . Since Equation is valid for every real number u, letting u = x^3 tells us that Equation is valid for every real number x. The Ratio Test can be used to show that multiplying every term of a Taylor series by the same power of x does not change the set of x-values for which the series converges, so the Taylor series for g(x) also converges for every value of x.

subsection.title: Differentiating and integrating Taylor series
subsection.p:
In Section, we discussed the challenge posed by the definite integral
\int_0^1 e^{-x^2} \, dx . Because we are unable to find a simple algebraic antiderivative for the function e^{-x^2}, we cannot use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus to evaluate the integral exactly. We learned in Section that the Second Fundamental Theorem of Calculus provides us with an antiderivative of a given function by using an integral function: one antiderivative of f(x) = e^{-x^2} is
F(x) = \int_0^x e^{-u^2} \, du .

Our recent work with Taylor series now suggests another way to find an antiderivative F(x) for f(x) = e^{-x^2}, and this approach also provides new options for finding additional Taylor series. In Activity, we found that
e^{-x^2} = 1 - x^2 + \frac{1}{2!}x^4 - \frac{1}{3!}x^6 + \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{n!} x^{2n} + \cdots
and that this representation of e^{-x^2} is valid for every value of x. This infinite series representation suggests that we could find an antiderivative F(x) of e^{-x^2} by using Equation to actually evaluate the integral \int_0^x e^{-u^2} \, du . Doing so, we see
F(x) =\mathstrut \amp \int_0^x e^{-u^2} \, du =\mathstrut \amp \int_0^x \left( 1 - u^2 + \frac{1}{2!}u^4 - \frac{1}{3!}u^6 + \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{n!} u^{2n} + \cdots \right) \, du =\mathstrut \amp \left. u - \frac{1}{3}u^3 + \frac{1}{5 \cdot 2!} u^5 - \frac{1}{7 \cdot 3!}u^7 + \cdots + \frac{(-1)^n}{(2n+1)n!} u^{2n+1} + \cdots \right|_0^x =\mathstrut \amp \left(x - \frac{1}{3}x^3 + \frac{1}{5 \cdot 2!} x^5 - \frac{1}{7 \cdot 3!}x^7 + \cdots + \frac{(-1)^n}{(2n+1)n!} x^{2n+1} + \cdots \right) - 0 =\mathstrut \amp x - \frac{1}{3}x^3 + \frac{1}{5 \cdot 2!} x^5 - \frac{1}{7 \cdot 3!}x^7 + \cdots + \frac{(-1)^n}{(2n+1)n!} x^{2n+1} + \cdots

While it is natural to wonder how integrating a Taylor series might change the values of x for which the series converges, it turns out that integrating a power series has almost no effectIt is possible for the convergence status at the endpoints of the interval to change, but we are normally not concerned with those specific x-values. on where the series converges (nor does differentiating such a series). This fact is stated formally in a result called The Power Series Differentiation and Integration Theorem.

assemblage.title: The Power Series Differentiation and Integration Theorem

subsection.p: Stated more informally, the Power Series Differentiation and Integration Theorem tells us that when it comes to differentiating or integrating a Taylor series, we can do so just like if they were finite polynomials: we can differentiate or integrate the Taylor series term-wise following the Power Rule for differentiating or integrating x^n. Moreover, doing so doesn't change the interval on which the Taylor series convergesDifferentiating or integrating can change the convergence status at the endpoints of the interval, but we again will not concern ourselves with that issue in this course. Since polynomials are the easiest of all functions to differentiate and integrate, we can now find many more Taylor series of interesting functions.
Being able to easily differentiate or integrate a Taylor series will also enable us to apply Taylor series to solve problems involving definite integrals.

subsection.title: Alternating series of real numbers
subsection.p:
Let's return to the challenge posed by the definite integral
\int_0^1 e^{-x^2} \, dx . While we are unable to find an elementary antiderivative of e^{-x^2}, now that we know the Taylor series
e^{-x^2} = 1 - x^2 + \frac{1}{2!}x^4 - \frac{1}{3!}x^6 + \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{n!} x^{2n} + \cdots
if we apply the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus to the series representation of e^{-x^2}, we find that
\int_0^1 e^{-x^2} \, dx =\mathstrut \amp \int_0^1 \left( 1 - x^2 + \frac{1}{2!}x^4 - \frac{1}{3!}x^6 + \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{n!} x^{2n} + \cdots \right) \, dx =\mathstrut \amp \left. x - \frac{1}{3}x^3 + \frac{1}{5 \cdot 2!} x^5 + \cdots + \frac{(-1)^n}{(2n+1) n!} x^{2n+1} + \cdots \right|_0^1 =\mathstrut \amp \left(1 - \frac{1}{3} + \frac{1}{5 \cdot 2!} + \cdots + \frac{(-1)^n}{(2n+1) n!} + \cdots \right) - \left( 0 \right) =\mathstrut \amp 1 - \frac{1}{3} + \frac{1}{5 \cdot 2!} - \frac{1}{7 \cdot 3!} + \cdots + \frac{(-1)^n}{(2n+1) n!} + \cdots
The infinite series in Equation is an example of an alternating series of real numbers. It turns out to be straightforward to determine whether or not an alternating series converges, and also to estimate the sum of a convergent alternating series.

statement.p:
An alternating series is a series of the form
\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} (-1)^k a_k , where a_k \gt 0 for each k.

subsection.p: We will only consider alternating series for which the sequence of positive numbers a_k decreases to 0. The following example illustrates two general results that hold for any alternating series whose terms a_k decrease to 0. We use a geometric series so that we can know its exact sum and compare certain computations to that sum.

statement.p: Investigate the partial sums of the alternating geometric series S = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} (-1)^k \left( \frac{4}{5} \right)^k. How do the partial sums compare to the exact sum of the series, and how can partial sums accurately estimate the value of the sum?

solution.p:
First, recall that the nth partial sum is the sum of the first n terms, so
S_n = \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} (-1)^k \left( \frac{4}{5} \right)^k = 1 - \frac{4}{5} + \frac{16}{25} - \cdots + (-1)^{n-1} \left( \frac{4}{5} \right)^{n-1} . We compute the first 10 partial sums of the series and display the results in Table and plot the points (n, S_n) in .

table.title: Partial sums of the alternating series

figure.caption: Partial sums of the alternating series and the horizontal line y = \frac{5}{9}.

solution.p:
Because the given series S = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} (-1)^k \left( \frac{4}{5} \right)^k is geometric with a = 1 and r = -\frac{4}{5}, we know the series converges and its sum is
S = \frac{a}{1-r} = \frac{1}{1+\frac{4}{5}} = \frac{1}{\frac{3}{2}} = \frac{2}{3} . Knowing this value helps us better understand the behavior of the partial sums.

In both the table and the figure, we see how consecutive partial sums move back and forth above and below the exact sum of the infinite series, \frac{2}{3}, and moreover how the amount the next partial sum lies above or below \frac{2}{3} is less than the amount by which the previous partial sum deviated. For instance,
|S_5 - \frac{2}{3}| \approx 0.0208,
but
|S_6 - \frac{2}{3}| \approx 0.0104 . Moreover, since S_6 = S_5 - \left( \frac{4}{5} \right)^5, and -\left( \frac{4}{5} \right)^5 = -0.03125 is the last and smallest term (in absolute value) in S_6, 0.03125 is the total vertical distance from the point (5, S_5) to (6, S_6) in Figure. This implies that 0.03125 is more than the error in comparing S_5 and S. Said differently, we are guaranteed that
|S - S_5| \lt \left( \frac{4}{5} \right)^5
so the next term in the sum provides a bound on the error in a given partial sum. A similar argument can be made for any value of n.

subsection.p: The arguments Example can be made for any alternating series whose terms go to zero. This leads us to state two important results.

assemblage.title: The Alternating Series Test
assemblage.p:
Given an alternating series
\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} (-1)^k a_k , if the positive terms a_k decrease to 0 as k \to \infty, then the alternating series converges.

subsection.p: If we were to compute the partial sums S_n of any alternating series whose terms decrease to zero and plot the points (n,S_n) as we did in Figure, we would see a similar picture: the partial sums alternate above and below the value to which the infinite alternating series converges. In addition, because the terms go to zero, the amount a given partial sum deviates from the total sum is at most the next term in the series. This result is formally stated as the Alternating Series Estimation Theorem.

assemblage.title: Alternating Series Estimation Theorem
assemblage.p:
If the alternating series
\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} (-1)^{k+1}a_k
has positive terms a_k that decrease to zero as k \to \infty, and
S_n = \sum_{k=1}^{n} (-1)^{k+1}a_k
is the nth partial sum of the alternating series, then
\left\lvert \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} (-1)^{k+1}a_k - S_n \right\rvert \leq a_{n+1} .

subsection.p: Again, this result simply says: if we use a partial sum to estimate the exact sum of an alternating series, the error of the approximation is less than the next term in the series.

solution.p:
If we let S be the sum of the series \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^{k+1}}{k}, then we know that
\left| S_{100} - S \right| \lt a_{101} .

Now
a_{101} = \frac{1}{101} \approx 0.0099 , so the 100th partial sum is within 0.0099 of the exact sum of the series.

li.p:
Through substitution, we can use any known Taylor series to find the Taylor series of a related function. For example, we know that if |u| \lt 1,
\ln(1+u) = u - \frac{1}{2}u^2 + \frac{1}{3}u^3 - \frac{1}{4}u^4 + \cdots
Letting u = 4x^2, it follows that
\ln(1+4x^2) = 4x^2 - \frac{1}{2} \cdot 16x^4 + \frac{1}{3} \cdot 64x^6 - \frac{1}{4} \cdot 256x^8 + \cdots
and that this representation converges if |4x^2| \lt 1, so for x such that |x| \lt \frac{1}{2}.

The Power Series Differentation and Integration Theorem tells us that we can differentiate or integrate a Taylor series in the natural way and that doing so has essentially no impact on the set of x-values for which the series converges. For instance, we might note that if we first found the Taylor series for \sin(x), which is
\sin(x) = x - \frac{1}{3!}x^3 + \frac{1}{5!}x^5 - \frac{1}{7!}x^7 + \cdots
and converges for every value of x, it follows by differentating that
\cos(x) =\mathstrut \amp \frac{d}{dx}[\sin(x)] =\mathstrut \amp \frac{d}{dx}[x - \frac{1}{3!}x^3 + \frac{1}{5!}x^5 - \frac{1}{7!}x^7 + \cdots] =\mathstrut \amp 1 - \frac{1}{3!} \cdot 3x^2 + \frac{1}{5!} \cdot 5x^4 - \frac{1}{7!} \cdot 7x^6 + \cdots =\mathstrut \amp 1 - \frac{1}{2!}x^2 + \frac{1}{4!} x^4 - \frac{1}{6!} x^6 + \cdots
which is precisely the Taylor series for \cos(x) that we found by taking derivatives and applying Definition.
